para.paratext: Under O.C.G.A. § 9-11-36(a), a party may request that the other party admit the genuineness of any relevant document in any civil action in any court of record in Georgia.[1] A copy of the document should accompany the request or be made available.

A party's admission that the document is genuine dispenses with the need for further authentication. If the opposing party denies the genuineness of the document and the requesting party proves the document is genuine at trial, he may request that the court order payment of reasonable expenses incurred in making such proof, including attorney's fees.

Since Georgia courts have determined that the language in O.C.G.A. § 9-11-36(a) is clear, unambiguous, and unequivocal, a party must comply strictly with the terms of the statute or risk having his response construed to be an admission.[2]

Any fact admitted is conclusively established unless the court permits the affected party to withdraw or amend the admission.[3] The trial court is vested with broad discretion to permit withdrawal of admissions, and its ruling may be reversed only upon a showing of abuse of discretion.[4]
An admission under O.C.G.A. § 9-11-36, or a failure to reply, admits only that the document is the one involved and does not admit its accuracy or the truth of its content.[5]
In federal court, under Fed. R. Civ. P. 16 and 36, a party may also demand that a writing be authenticated.[6]
JJM Trucking, Inc. v. Caterpillar Financial Services Corp., 295 Ga. App. 560, 672 S.E.2d 529 (2009).
O.C.G.A. § 9-11-36(b); JJM Trucking, Inc. v. Caterpillar Financial Services Corp., 295 Ga. App. 560, 672 S.E.2d 529 (2009).

Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 9-11-36, a party may serve upon another party a written request for the admission of the truth of any matter that is not privileged and is relevant to the pending action, including a request to admit the genuineness of any documents described therein. Where the request is served with the summons and complaint, the defendant must serve a written answer or objection thereto within 45 days, or else the matter is deemed admitted.

The trial court is vested with broad discretion to permit withdrawal of an admission made by reason of the failure to make a timely response to the request. Velasco v. Chambless, 295 Ga. App. 376, 671 S.E.2d 870 (2008).

Failure to present admissible, credible evidence contradicting the admitted matters justifies the denial of the motion to withdraw admissions. Porter v. Urban Residential Development Corp., 294 Ga. App. 828, 670 S.E.2d 464 (2008).
Fulton County v. SOCO Contracting Company, Inc., 343 Ga. App. 889, 808, 808 S.E.2d 891 (2017).
Stalvey v. Osceola Industries, Inc., 124 Ga. App. 708, 185 S.E.2d 629 (1971).
